titleStmt.title: Hybrid viscosity approximation schemes for equilibrium problems and fixed point problems of infinitely many nonexpansive mappings

analytic.title: Hybrid viscosity approximation schemes for equilibrium problems and fixed point problems of infinitely many nonexpansive mappings

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Recently, Takahashi and Takahashi [S. Takahashi, W. Takahashi, Viscosity approximation methods for equilibrium problems and fixed point problems in Hilbert spaces,

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Let H be a real Hilbert space with inner product hÁ; Ái and norm k Á k. Let C be a nonempty closed convex subset of H and / : C Â C ! R be a bifunction of C Â C into R, where R is the set of real numbers. The equilibrium problem for / : C Â C ! R is to find u 2 C such that /ðu; vÞ P 0 for all v 2 C: ð1:1Þ The set of solutions of (1.1) is denoted by EP ð/Þ. The equilibrium problem (1.1) includes as special cases numerous problems in physics, optimization, and economics. Some authors have proposed some useful methods for solving the equilibrium problem (1.1); see, e.g., [2,3,12].
A mapping f : H ! H of H into itself is called contractive if there exists a constant a 2 ½0; 1Þ such that kf ðxÞ À f ðyÞk 6 akx À yk for all x; y 2 H :
A mapping T : C ! H of C into H is called nonexpansive if kTx À Tyk 6 kx À yk for all x; y 2 C:

We denote by F ðT Þ the set of fixed points of T, i.e., F ðT Þ ¼ fx 2 C : Tx ¼ xg. It is well known that if C & H is nonempty, bounded, closed and convex and T is a nonexpansive self-mapping on C then F ðT Þ is nonempty; see, e.g., [13]. In 2000, Moudafi [4] proved the following strong convergence theorem.

Theorem 1.1 (cf. [4]). Let C be a nonempty closed convex subset of a Hilbert space H and let T be a nonexpansive self-mapping on C such that F ðT Þ 6 ¼ ;. Let f : C ! C be a contraction and let fx n g be a sequence defined as follows: Then, fx n g converges strongly to z 2 F ðT Þ, where z ¼ P F ðT Þ f ðzÞ and P F ðT Þ is the metric projection of H onto F ðT Þ.
div.formula: x 1 ¼ x 2 C and x nþ1 ¼ 1 1 þ e n Tx n þ e n 1 þ
div.p: Such a method for approximation of fixed points is called the viscosity approximation method. Very recently, motivated by Combettes and Hirstoaga [2], Moudafi [4] and Tada and Takahashi [7], Takahashi and Takahashi [12] introduced an iterative scheme by the viscosity approximation method for finding a common element of the set of solutions of (1.1) and the set of fixed points of a nonexpansive mapping in a Hilbert space, and proved the following strong convergence theorem which is connected with the results in [2,11]. (A4) for each x 2 C, y 7 ! /ðx; yÞ is convex and lower semicontinuous.
div.formula: Let T : C ! H be a nonexpansive mapping such that F ðT Þ \ EP ð/Þ 6 ¼ ;, let f : H ! H be
div.p: a contraction and let fx n g and fu n g be sequences generated by x 1 2 H and
div.formula: /ðu n ; yÞ þ 1 rn hy À u n ; u n À x n i P 0; 8y 2 C; x nþ1 ¼ a n f ðx n Þ þ ð1 À
a n ¼ 0; X 1 n¼1 a n ¼ 1; X 1 n¼1 ja nþ1 À a n j < 1; lim inf n!1 r n > 0 and X 1 n¼1 jr nþ1 À r n j < 1:
div.p: Then, fx n g and fu n g converge strongly to z 2
div.formula: F ðT Þ \ EP ð/Þ, where z ¼ P F ðT Þ\EP ð/Þ f ðzÞ.
div.p: On the other hand, very recently, Zeng and Yao [9] introduced and studied an implicit iteration process with perturbed mapping for finding a common fixed point of finitely many nonexpansive mappings in H. Subsequently, Yao et al. [8] introduced and considered an iterative scheme for finding a common element of the set of solutions of the equilibrium problem (1.1) and the set of common fixed points of infinitely many nonexpansive mappings in H. Let fT n g 1 n¼1 be a sequence of nonexpansive mappings of C into itself and let fk n g 1 n¼1 be a sequence of nonnegative numbers in ½0; 1. For each n P 1, define a mapping W n of C into itself as follows:
div.formula: U n;nþ1 ¼ I; U n;n ¼ k n T n U n;nþ1 þ ð1 À k n ÞI; U n;nÀ1 ¼ k nÀ1 T nÀ1 U n;n þ ð1 À k nÀ1 ÞI;
U n;k ¼ k k T k U n;kþ1 þ ð1 À k k ÞI; U n;kÀ1 ¼ k kÀ1 T kÀ1 U n;k þ ð1 À k kÀ1 ÞI;
U n;2 ¼ k 2 T 2 U n;3 þ ð1 À k 2 ÞI; W n ¼ U n;1 ¼ k 1 T 1 U n;2 þ ð1 À k 1 ÞI: ð1:3Þ
div.p: Such a mapping W n is called the W-mapping generated by T n ; T nÀ1 ; . . . ; T 1 and k n ; k nÀ1 ; . . . ; k 1 ; see [14]. Then, Yao et al. [8] proved the following strong convergence theorem.

Theorem 1.3 (see [8], Theorem 3.1). Let C be a nonempty closed convex subset of a real Hilbert space H. Let / : C Â C ! R be a bifunction satisfying (A1)-(A4) and let fT n g 1 n¼1 be a sequence of nonexpansive mappings of C into itself such that
div.formula: T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ \ EP ð/Þ 6 ¼ ;
div.p: . Suppose fa n g; fb n g and fc n g are three sequences in ð0; 1Þ and fr n g & ð0; 1Þ is a real sequence. Suppose the following conditions are satisfied:
div.formula: (i) lim n!1 a n ¼ 0 and P 1 n¼0 a n ¼ 1; (ii) 0 < lim inf n!1 b n 6 lim sup n!1 b n < 1; (iii) lim inf n!1 r n > 0 and lim n!1 ðr nþ1 À r n Þ ¼ 0.
div.p: Let f be a contraction of H into itself and given x 0 2 H arbitrarily. Then the sequences fx n g and fu n g generated iteratively by
div.formula: /ðu n ; xÞ þ 1 rn hx À u n ; u n À x n i P 0; 8x 2 C; x nþ1 ¼ a n f ðx n Þ þ b n x n þ c n W n u n ; ( ð1:4Þ
div.p: where fk n g is a sequence in ð0; b for some b 2 ð0; 1Þ, converge strongly to
div.formula: x Ã 2 T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ \ EP ð/Þ, where x Ã ¼ P T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ\EP ð/Þ f ðx Ã Þ.
div.p: In this paper, inspired by Moudafi [4], Tada and Takahashi [7], Takahashi and Takahashi [12] and Yao et al. [8], we introduce a new iterative scheme by the viscosity approximation method:
div.formula: /ðu n ; xÞ þ 1 rn hx À u n ; u n À x n i P 0; 8x 2 C; y n ¼ ð1 À c n Þx n þ c n W n u n ; x nþ1 ¼ ð1 À a n À b n Þx n þ a n f ðy n Þ þ b n W n y n ; 8 > < > : ð1:5Þ
div.p: where fa n g; fb n g and fc n g are three sequences in ð0; 1Þ such that a n þ b n 6 1, for finding a common element of the set of solutions of the equilibrium problem (1.1) and the set of common fixed points of infinitely many nonexpansive mappings in a Hilbert space. Then, we prove a strong convergence theorem which is the improvements and development of Theorem 3.1 in Yao et al. [8]. Using this theorem, we obtain two corollaries which improve and develop their corresponding results.

div.head: Preliminaries
div.p: Let H be a real Hilbert space with inner product hÁ; Ái and norm k Á k. We denote weak convergence and strong convergence by notations * and !, respectively. Let C be a nonempty closed convex subset of H. Then, for any x 2 H , there exists a unique nearest point in C, denoted by P C ðxÞ, such that kx À P C ðxÞk 6 kx À yk 8y 2 C:
div.formula: Such a P C is called the metric projection of H onto C. It is known that P C is nonexpansive. Further, for x 2 H and z 2 C, z ¼ P C x () hx À z; z À yi P 0 8y 2 C:
div.p: The following lemmas will be used for the proof of our main results in the sequel.
Lemma 2.1 (cf. [1,2]). Let C be a nonempty closed convex subset of H and let / : C Â C ! R be a bifunction satisfying (A1)-(A4). Let r > 0 and x 2 H . Then, there exists z 2 C such that
div.formula: /ðz; yÞ þ 1 r hy À z; z À xi P 0 8y 2 C: Lemma 2.2 (cf. [2]). Assume that / : C Â C ! R satisfies (A1)-(A4).
div.p: For r > 0 and x 2 H , define a mapping T r : H ! C as follows:
div.formula: T r x ¼ z 2 C : /ðz; yÞ þ 1 r hy À z; z À xi P 0; 8y 2 C
div.p: for all x 2 H . Then, the following hold:
(i) T r is single-valued;
(ii) T r is firmly nonexpansive, i.e., for any x; y 2 H kT r x À T r yk 2 6 hT r x À T r y; x À yi;
div.formula: (iii) F ðT r Þ ¼ EP ð/Þ; (iv) EP ð/Þ is closed and convex.
div.p: Lemma 2.3 (see [10,Lemma 2.5]). Let fa n g be a sequence of nonnegative numbers such that a nþ1 6 ð1 À l n Þa n þ l n m n ; n ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; where fl n g is a sequence in ð0; 1Þ and fm n g is a sequence in R such that
div.formula: (i) P 1 n¼1 l n ¼ 1; (ii) lim sup n!1 m n 6 0 or P 1 n¼1 jl n m n j < 1. Then, lim n!1 a n ¼ 0.
div.p: Lemma 2.4 (see Opial's theorem [5]). Each Hilbert space H satisfies Opial's condition, i.e., for any sequence
div.formula: fx n g & H with x n * x, the inequality lim inf n!1 kx n À xk < lim inf n!1
div.p: kx n À yk holds for each y 2 H with x 6 ¼ y.
Lemma 2.5. Let H be a real Hilbert space. Then, for all x; y 2
div.formula: H kx þ yk 2 6 kxk 2 þ 2hy; x þ yi:
div.p: Proof. Obvious.
Lemma 2.6 (cf. [6]). Let fx n g and fz n g be bounded sequences in a Banach space X and let f. n g be a sequence in ½0;
div.formula: 1 with 0 < lim inf n!1 . n 6 lim sup n!1 . n < 1. Suppose that x nþ1 ¼ . n x n þ ð1 À . n Þz n for all n P 0 and lim sup n!1 ðkz nþ1 À z n k À kx nþ1 À x n kÞ 6 0. Then, lim n!1 kz n À x n k ¼ 0.
div.p: Let fT n g 1 n¼1 be a sequence of nonexpansive mappings of C into itself, where C is a nonempty closed convex subset of a real Hilbert space H. Given a sequence fk n g 1 n¼1 in ½0; 1, we define a sequence fW n g 1 n¼1 of self-mappings on C by (1.3). Then we have the following results. Lemma 2.7 (see [14,Lemma 3.2]). Let C be a nonempty closed convex subset of a real Hilbert space H. Let fT n g 1 n¼1 be a sequence of nonexpansive self-mappings on C such that T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ 6 ¼ ; and let fk n g be a sequence in ð0; b for some b 2 ð0; 1Þ. Then, for every x 2 C and k P 1 the limit lim n!1 U n;k x exists.

div.head: Strong convergence theorem
div.p: In this section, we deal with the strong convergence of hybrid viscosity approximation scheme (1.5) for finding a common element of the set of solutions of the equilibrium problem (1.1) and the set of common fixed points of infinitely many nonexpansive mappings in a Hilbert space. Theorem 3.1. Let C be a nonempty closed convex subset of a real Hilbert space H. Let / : C Â C ! R be a bifunction satisfying (A1)-(A4) and let fT n g 1 n¼1 be a sequence of nonexpansive self-mappings on C such that
div.formula: T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ \ EP ð/Þ 6 ¼ ;
div.p: . Suppose fa n g; fb n g and fc n g are sequences in ð0; 1Þ such that a n þ b n 6 1 and fr n g & ð0; 1Þ is a real sequence. Suppose the following conditions are satisfied:
div.formula: (i) lim n!1 a n ¼ 0 and P 1 n¼0 a n ¼ 1; (ii) 0 < lim inf n!1 b n 6 lim sup n!1 b n < 1; (iii) 0 < lim inf n!1 c n 6 lim sup n!1 c n < 1 and lim n!1 jc nþ1 À c n j ¼ 0; (iv) 0 < lim inf n!1 r n and lim n!1 jr nþ1 À r n j ¼ 0.
div.p: Let f be a contraction of C into itself and given x 0 2 C arbitrarily. Then the sequences fx n g and fu n g generated iteratively by (1.5) where fk n g is a sequence in ð0; b for some b 2 ð0; 1Þ, converge strongly to
div.formula: x Ã 2 T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ\ EP ð/Þ, where x Ã ¼ P T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ\EP ð/Þ f ðx Ã Þ. Proof. Let Q ¼ P T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ\EP ð/Þ
div.p: . Note that f is a contraction with constant a 2 ½0; 1Þ. Then kQf ðxÞ À Qf ðyÞk 6 kf ðxÞ À f ðyÞk 6 akx À yk for all x; y 2 C. Therefore, Qf is a contraction of C into itself, which implies that there exists a unique element
div.formula: x Ã 2 C such that x Ã ¼ Qf ðx Ã Þ. Let p 2 T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ \ EP ð/Þ.
div.p: From the definition of T r , we know that u n ¼ T r n x n . It follows that ku n À pk ¼ kT rn x n À T rn pk 6 kx n À pk; and hence
div.formula: ky n À pk ¼ kð1 À c n Þðx n À pÞ þ c n ðW n u n À pÞk 6 ð1 À c n Þkx n À pk þ c n kW n u n À pÞk 6 ð1 À c n Þkx n À pk þ c n ku n À pk 6 ð1 À c n Þkx n À pk þ c n kx n À pk ¼ kx n À pk:
div.p: First, we claim that fx n g and fy n g are bounded. Indeed, From (1.3) and (1.5) we obtain
div.formula: kx nþ1 À pk ¼ kð1 À a n À b n Þx n þ af ðy n Þ þ b n W n y n À pk 6 ð1 À a n À b n Þkx n À pk þ a n kf ðy n Þ À pk þ b n kW n y n À pk 6 ð1 À a n À b n Þkx n À pk þ a n ðkf ðy n Þ À f ðpÞk þ kf ðpÞ À pkÞ þ b n ky n À pk 6 ð1 À a n À b n Þkx n À pk þ a n ðaky n À pk þ kf ðpÞ À pkÞ þ b n ky n À pk 6 ð1 À a n À b n Þkx n À pk þ a n ðakx n À pk þ kf ðpÞ À pkÞ þ b n kx n À pk 6 ð1 À ð1 À aÞa n Þkx n À pk þ ðð1 À aÞa n Þ Á 1 1 À a kf ðpÞ À pk 6 max kx n À pk; 1 1 À a kf ðpÞ À pk :
div.p: By induction, kx n À pk 6 max kx 0 À pk; 1 1 À a kf ðpÞ À pk ; 8n P 0:
Hence it follows that fx n g is bounded, and so are fu n g; fy n g; fW n u n g; fW n y n g and ff ðy n Þg.
Second, we claim that lim n!1 kx nþ1 À x n k ¼ 0. Indeed, define a sequence fz n g by
div.formula: x nþ1 ¼ . n x n þ ð1 À . n Þz n ; 8n P 0;
div.p: where . n ¼ 1 À a n À b n ; 8n P 0. Then we have

kW nþ1 y nþ1 À W nþ1 y n k 6 ky nþ1 À y n k ¼ kð1 À c nþ1 Þx nþ1 þ c nþ1 W nþ1 u nþ1 À ð1 À c n Þx n À c n W n u n k 6 ð1 À c nþ1 Þkx nþ1 À x n k þ jc nþ1 À c n jkx n k þ c nþ1 kW nþ1 u nþ1 À W n u n k þ jc nþ1 À c n jkW n u n k 6 ð1 À c nþ1 Þkx nþ1 À x n k þ jc nþ1 À c n jkx n k þ c nþ1 ðkW nþ1 u nþ1 À W nþ1 u n k þ kW nþ1 u n À W n u n kÞ þ jc nþ1 À c n jkW n u n k 6 ð1 À c nþ1 Þkx nþ1 À x n k þ jc nþ1 À c n jkx n k þ c nþ1 ðku nþ1 À u n k þ kW nþ1 u n À W n u n kÞ þ jc nþ1 À c n jkW n u n k: ð3:2Þ
div.p: From (1.3), since T i and U n;i are nonexpansive, we deduce that for each n P 1

div.p: hu n À u nþ1 ; u nþ1 À x nþ1 i P 0:
So, from (A2) we have

div.p: and hence
div.formula: u nþ1 À u n ; u n À u nþ1 þ u nþ1 À x n À r n r nþ1 ðu nþ1 À x nþ1 Þ P 0:
div.p: Without loss of generality, we may assume that there exists a real number r such that r n > r > 0 for all n P 0. Then we have
div.formula: ku nþ1 À u n k 2 6 u nþ1 À u n ; x nþ1 À x n þ 1 À r n r nþ1 ðu nþ1 À x nþ1 Þ 6 ku nþ1 À u n k kx nþ1 À x n k þ 1 À r n r nþ1 ku nþ1 À x nþ1 k ; ku nþ1 À u n k 6 kx nþ1 À x n k þ 1 À r n r nþ1 ku nþ1 À x nþ1 k 6 kx nþ1 À x n k þ 1 r jr nþ1 À

kW nþ1 y nþ1 À W nþ1 y n k 6 ð1 À c nþ1 Þkx nþ1 À x n k þ jc nþ1 À c n jkx n k þ c nþ1 ðku nþ1 À u n kÞ þ c nþ1 kW nþ1 u n À W n u n k þ jc nþ1 À c n jkW n u n k 6 ð1 À c nþ1 Þkx nþ1 À x n k þ jc nþ1 À c n jkx n k þ c nþ1 kx nþ1 À x n k þ 1 r jr nþ1 À r n jL þ c nþ1 M Y n i¼1 k i þ jc nþ1 À c n jkW n u n k 6 kx nþ1 À x n k þ jc nþ1 À c n jkx n k þ 1 r jr nþ1 À r n jL þ M Y n i¼1 k i þ jc nþ1 À c n jkW n u n k: ð3:8Þ
div.p: Combining (3.1), (3.4) and (3.8), we obtain
div.formula: kz nþ1 À z n k À kx nþ1 À x n k 6 a nþ1 1 À . nþ1 ðkf ðy nþ1 Þk þ kW nþ1 y n kÞ þ a n 1 À . n ðkf ðy n Þk þ kW n y n kÞ þ b nþ1 1 À . nþ1 kW nþ1 y nþ1 À W nþ1 y n k þ kW nþ1 y n À W n y n k À kx nþ1 À x n k 6 a nþ1 1 À . nþ1 ðkf ðy nþ1 Þk þ kW nþ1 y n kÞ þ a n 1 À . n ðkf ðy n Þk þ kW n y n kÞ þ b nþ1 1 À . nþ1 kx nþ1 À x n k þ jc nþ1 À c n jkx n k þ 1 r jr nþ1 À r n jL þ M Y n i¼1 k i þ jc nþ1 À c n jkW n u n k ( ) þ M Y n i¼1 k i À kx nþ1 À x n k 6 a nþ1 1 À . nþ1 ðkf ðy nþ1 Þk þ kW nþ1 y n kÞ þ a n 1 À . n ðkf ðy n Þk þ kW n y n kÞ þ b nþ1 1 À . nþ1 ( jc nþ1 À c n jkx n k þ 1 r jr nþ1 À r n jL þ M Y n i¼1 k i þ jc nþ1 À c n jkW n u n k ) þ M Y n i¼1 k i : ð3:9Þ
div.p: Thus it follows from (3.9) and conditions (i)-(iv) that (noting that 0 < k i 6 b < 1; 8i P 1)

Thus by Lemma 2.6 we obtain lim n!1

div.p: From (3.7) and lim n!1 jr nþ1 À r n j ¼ 0, we have
div.formula: lim n!1 ku nþ1 À u n k ¼ 0: Since x nþ1 ¼ ð1 À a n À b n Þx n þ a n f ðy n Þ þ b n W n y n , we have kx n À W n y n k 6 kx n À x nþ1 k þ kx nþ1 À W n y n k 6 kx n À x nþ1 k þ ð1 À a n À b n Þkx n À W n y n k þ a n kf ðy n Þ À W n y n k;
div.p: that is,
div.formula: kx n À W n y n k 6 1 a n þ b n kx n À x nþ1 k þ a n a n þ b n kf ðy n Þ À W n y n k: It follows that lim n!1 kx n À W n y n k ¼ 0: ð3:11Þ For p 2 T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ \ EP ð/Þ, since T r is firmly nonexpansive, we have llku n À pk 2 ¼ kT rn x n À T rn pk 2 6 hT rn x n À T rn p; x n À pi ¼ hu n À p; x n À pi ¼ 1 2 ðku n À pk 2 þ kx n À pk 2 À kx n À u n k 2 Þ;
div.p: and hence
div.formula: ku n À pk 2 6 kx n À pk 2 À kx n À u n k 2 :
div.p: Therefore, we have
div.formula: kx nþ1 À pk 2 ¼ kð1 À a n À b n Þðx n À pÞ þ a n ðf ðy n Þ À pÞ þ b n ðW n y n À pÞk 2 6 ð1 À a n À b n Þkx n À pk 2 þ a n kf ðy n Þ À pk 2 þ b n kW n y n À pk 2 6 ð1 À a n À b n Þkx n À pk 2 þ a n kf ðy n Þ À pk 2 þ b n ky n À pk 2 ¼ ð1 À a n À b n Þkx n À pk 2 þ a n kf ðy n Þ À pk 2 þ b n kð1 À c n Þðx n À pÞ þ c n ðW n u n À pÞk 2 6 ð1 À a n À b n Þkx n À pk 2 þ a n kf ðy n Þ À pk 2 þ b n ½ð1 À c n Þkx n À pk 2 þ c n kW n u n À pk 2 6 ð1 À a n À b n Þkx n À pk 2 þ a n kf ðy n Þ À pk 2 þ b n ½ð1 À c n Þkx n À pk 2 þ c n ku n À pk 2 6 ð1 À a n À b n Þkx n À pk 2 þ a n kf ðy n Þ À pk 2 þ b n ½ð1 À c n Þkx n À pk 2 þ c n ðkx n À pk 2 À kx n À u n k 2 Þ ¼ ð1 À a n Þkx n À pk 2 þ a n kf ðy n Þ À pk 2 À b n c n kx n À u n k 2 6 kx n À pk 2 þ a n kf ðy n Þ À pk 2 À b n c n kx n À u n k 2 :
div.p: Thus we have
div.formula: b n c n kx n À u n k 2 6 a n kf ðy n Þ À pk 2 þ kx n À pk 2 À kx nþ1 À pk 2 ¼ a n kf ðy n Þ À pk 2 þ ðkx n À pk þ kx nþ1 À pkÞðkx n À pk À kx nþ1 À pkÞ 6 a n kf ðy n Þ À pk 2 þ kx n À x nþ1 kðkx n À pk þ kx nþ1 À pkÞ:
div.p: Since lim inf n!1 b n > 0 and lim inf n!1 c n > 0, it is easy to see that lim inf n!1 b n c n > 0. So, we have
div.formula: lim n!1 kx n À u n k ¼ 0: ð3:12Þ
div.p: Observe that
div.formula: ky n À u n k 6 ky n À x n k þ kx n À u n k 6 c n kW n u n À x n k þ kx n À u n k 6 c n kW n u n À W n y n þ W n y n À x n k þ kx n À u n k 6 c n ½ku n À y n k þ kW n y n À x n k þ kx n À u n k;
div.p: and hence
div.formula: ð1 À c n Þky n À u n k 6 kW n y n À x n k þ kx n À u n k:
div.p: Thus, from (3.11), (3.12) and lim sup n!1 c n < 1, we derive lim n!1

Therefore w 2 T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ \ EP ð/Þ. Since x Ã ¼ P T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ\EP ð/Þ f ðx Ã Þ, we have lim sup n!1 hf ðx Ã Þ À x Ã ; x n À x Ã i ¼ lim j!1 hf ðx Ã Þ À x Ã ; x nj À x Ã i ¼ lim j!1 hf ðx Ã Þ À x Ã ; u nj À x Ã i ¼ hf ðx Ã Þ À x Ã ; w À x Ã i 6 0: ð3:15Þ
div.p: Finally we claim that fx n g converges strongly to
div.formula: x Ã ¼ P T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ\EP ð/Þ f ðx Ã Þ.
div.p: Indeed, from (1.5) and Lemma 2.5 we obtain
div.formula: /ðu n ; xÞ þ 1 rn hx À u n ; u n À x n i P 0; 8x 2 C; x nþ1 ¼ ð1 À a n À b n Þx n þ a n f ðð1 À c n Þx n þ c n u n Þ þ b n ½ð1 À c n Þx n þ c n u n ; converge strongly to x Ã 2 EP ð/Þ, where x Ã ¼ P EP ð/Þ f ðx Ã Þ.
div.p: Proof. Put T i x ¼ x for all i ¼ 1; 2; . . . and for all x 2 C in (1.3). Then W n x ¼ x for all x 2 C. The conclusion follows immediately from Theorem 3.1. This completes the proof. h Corollary 3.2. Let C be a nonempty closed convex subset of a real Hilbert space H. Let fT n g 1 n¼1 be a sequence of nonexpansive self-mappings on C such that T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ 6 ¼ ;. Suppose fa n g; fb n g and fc n g are sequences in ð0; 1Þ such that a n þ b n 6 1. Suppose the following conditions are satisfied:
(i) lim n!1 a n ¼ 0 and P 1 n¼0 a n ¼ 1; (ii) 0 < lim inf n!1 b n 6 lim sup n!1 b n < 1; (iii) 0 < lim inf n!1 c n 6 lim sup n!1 c n < 1 and lim n!1 jc nþ1 À c n j ¼ 0.
Let f be a contraction of C into itself and given x 0 2 C arbitrarily. Then the sequence fx n g generated iteratively by
div.formula: y n ¼ ð1 À c n Þx n þ c n W n P C x n ; x nþ1 ¼ ð1 À a n À b n Þx n þ a n f ðy n Þ þ b n W n y n ;
div.p: where fk n g is a sequence in ð0; b for some b 2 ð0; 1Þ, converges strongly to x Ã 2 T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ, where
div.formula: x Ã ¼ P T 1 n¼1 F ðT n Þ f ðx Ã Þ.
div.p: Proof. Set /ðx; yÞ ¼ 0 for all x; y 2 C and r n ¼ 1 for all n P 0. Then, we have u n ¼ P C x n . From (1.5) we get
div.formula: y n ¼ ð1 À c n Þx n þ c n W n P C x n ; x nþ1 ¼ ð1 À a n À b n Þx n þ a n f ðy n Þ þ b n W n y n :
div.p: ( Then the conclusion follows immediately from Theorem 3.1. This completes the proof. h Remark 3.1. The main result of Takahashi and Takahashi [12] (see Theorem 1.2) improves, extends and unifies the corresponding theorems in Wittmann [11] and Combettes and Hirstoaga [2]. Our Theorem 3.1 improves and extends [12,Theorem 1.2] in the following aspects: (i) one nonexpansive mapping is replaced by infinitely many asymptotically nonexpansive mappings; (ii) our iterative process (1.5) is very different from Takahashi and Takahashi iterative process (1.2) because there are infinitely many nonexpansive mappings; (iii) our restrictions on the iterative parameters are very different from the ones in [12], for instance, the conditions P 1 n¼1 ja nþ1 À a n j < 1 and P 1 n¼1 jr nþ1 À r n j < 1 in Theorem 1.2 are removed; (iv) our iterative process (1.5) is more general than (1.2) because it can be applied to solving the problem of finding a common element of the set of solutions of the equilibrium problem (1.1) and the set of common fixed points of infinite many nonexpansive mappings; (v) our method of proof is very different from the one in [12], for example, we use ([10, Lemma 2.5], [14, Lemmas 3.2 and 3.3]) and Suzuki's lemma for the proof of Theorem 3.1.

As direct consequences of Theorem 3.1, we obtain two corollaries.

Corollary 3.1. Let C be a nonempty closed convex subset of a real Hilbert space H. Let / : C Â C ! R be a bifunction satisfying (A1)-(A4) such that EP ð/Þ 6 ¼ ;.
